instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power on, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Good morning, i have a mac that is not turning on. I also noticed that the charger LED is flickering on the brightness (I tested more than 1 charger).
I performed the following measurements:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.55V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.48V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 12.55V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL>: 12.55V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0V ~ 1.8V (PULSING)
<SIGNAL>P5VSUS_SS</SIGNAL>: 0V ~ 4.5V  (PULSING)
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 0V ~ 3V (PULSING)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>: 0V

Should I measure something else? Thank you.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power on, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at all big coils.
If no short at L7260, remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and check if get steady voltage at L7220/60.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power on, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Inverse diode values on big coils:

L7260: 0V (shorted to ground in continuity mode)
L7220: 0,153V
L7330: 0,153V
L7550: 0V (shorted to ground in continuity mode)
L7510: 0V (shorted to ground in continuity mode)
L7520: 0V (shorted to ground in continuity mode)
L7100: 0V (shorted to ground in continuity mode)
L7630: 0V (shorted to ground in continuity mode)
L7030: 0,458V
L7760: 0,162V
L3895: 0,530V
L7770: 0,347V
L7700: 0,308V

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power on, no fan spin.
threads.message:
I can't believe to have all these coils with short to ground.
Switch to ohm scale for very low values.

CPU coils have 001-003 ohm as normal for i7-i5 Ivy Bridge CPU; so pretty sure no short at L7510/20/50.

"L7260: 0V (shorted to ground in continuity mode)"
This is your problem.
You should be able to find the culprit with voltage injection method.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power on, no fan spin.
threads.message:
"CPU coils have 001-003 ohm as normal for i7-i5 Ivy Bridge CPU"
Noted, thank you!

Using the voltage injection method, I found <CAPACITOR>C6213</CAPACITOR> shorted, replaced it and the short was resolved. 5V and 3V voltages are now stable.
The board now rotates the fan, but has no logical activity.

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>: 1.1V stucked (Should decrease after a few seconds, correct?)

I also tested other RAM memories, same story. Even without memory, it did not have the characteristic BIP.
What should I do now? Thanks so far.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power on, no fan spin.
threads.message:
Any history available?

Try known good BIOS, just in case.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power on, no fan spin.
threads.message:
"Try known good BIOS" 
I made it, and it worked. Thank you for the support!
